speaker: Jan Spille
transcript: Sure. My name is Jan Spille. I'm at the University of Illinois in Chicago and I'm in the physics department. We are interested in how the cell nucleus is organized, in particular how the interplay of chromatin scaffolding and then protein condensation on top of that allows you to regulate transcription. And I'm an experimentalist so we do a lot of single molecule super resolution imaging, but I'm also very interested in talking with people who do modeling for example or synthetic stuff so we can get a better systematic understanding of what's going on.
other: He explicitly states his interest in collaborating with people with different expertise (modeling, synthetic biology).

We want to know how receptors self-organized and organized and have synergistic signaling for immune functions.

speaker: Gulcin Pekkurnaz
transcript: I can start because I don't work on phase separation. We're stumbled upon something I'm trying to even understand whether it's a phase separation or but one question I have, how many phases or how do we know what one phase is different than another? What like how many phases and how do we define that? And what distinguishes one phase from another? Are there any classifications in the field? We talked about

annotations.identify gap: The speaker explicitly states that she doesn't work on phase separation, recognizing her lack of expertise in the area.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Those of you who work on this, any any suggestions there?

speaker: Jan Spille
transcript: I think so I would go first too so I can focus on the writing as well. And also because that's exactly what what we're thinking about. So what we're I think starting to see or going to start seeing is that there is so much complexity in this whole phase separation field. It's not just a liquid and a liquid. So so what we're thinking about is how do complex multi-phase assemblies arise from from complex systems that you have in the cell as compared to your simple reconstitution systems where you have maybe one, two, three components but in the cell you have dozens. So there are certainly many phases. You can think about material properties I would say. You can have several liquid phases that that coexist but that have different composition and are therefore different phases. But they can also have different material properties like more gel-like, more glass-like or liquid-like. Maybe at some point it transitions into a stable aggregate then the question is is that still what we're talking about or what do we not care about that because it is a stable assembly and there are no dynamics for example.

annotations.develop idea: Jan Spille is expanding on the complexity of the phase separation field, discussing multi-phase assemblies and material properties.
annotations.ask question: Jan Spille asks a question about whether a stable aggregate is still considered part of what they're discussing.
annotations.signal expertise: Jan Spille is sharing insights based on their work, indicating their expertise in the area.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: I think it's very interesting and helpful. Does anybody else have anything they want to add to that?

annotations.Supportive response: The speaker expresses a positive evaluation of a previous contribution.
annotations.Ask question: The speaker requests information or input from other team members.
annotations.Encourage participation: The speaker invites others to contribute their thoughts or ideas.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: I'd just like to add about the the idea of different biomolecular condensates with different compositions and then that leads to the question of what are the rules of demixing of different phase separated structures. So if you have a biomolecular condensate that's involved in RNA biochemistry versus one that's involved in metabolism or different cellular processes like what if you look at those sequences what about them causes them to to phase separate from one another or to demix into distinct states. I feel like understanding those rules will be important moving forward.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas about biomolecular condensates by inquiring about the rules of demixing and the role of different compositions or sequences.
annotations.ask question: The speaker directly asks questions about the rules of demixing of different phase-separated structures and what causes phase separation or demixing.

speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: So I have a question maybe the bacteria. Are there phase separated or condensates that don't have nucleic acids? I know that like in vitro you can make them but in vivo do we find condensates that don't have nucleic acids or are they kind of a universal in vivo and again I think this multivalency it makes sense they're these super repetitive low information and so it makes sense that they would be in there but are there non-nucleic acid phase separated

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting information about the existence of phase-separated condensates without nucleic acids in bacteria, comparing in vitro and in vivo scenarios.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: Yeah and in at least in bacteria there there are condensates that largely co-localize signaling pathways that have a scaffolding protein that is the principal protein that phase separates. This is a protein called PopZ in Caulobacter and then they recruit a set of histidine kinases.

annotations.develop idea: Seth Childers is elaborating on the concept of condensates in bacteria, providing specific examples and details about the protein PopZ in Caulobacter and its role in signaling pathways.

speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: And nucleic acids are excluded from there?

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting information about whether nucleic acids are excluded from certain phase-separated condensates in bacteria, seeking clarification on a specific aspect of phase separation.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: Yes.

annotations.Supportive Response: This code applies because Seth Childers is expressing agreement or confirmation to Brian Zid's inquiry about the absence of nucleic acids in certain condensates.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Okay, that's very interesting. So somebody else have a question that they would like to throw out for the group?

speaker: Grace Stokes
transcript: I have a molecular like a very detailed question about thermodynamics. Usually my background is kind of studying how different phases in a homogeneous system like you can calculate the changes in energy from one phase to another when you have to transition between phases but it sounds like phase separated systems in biology are very complex and heterogeneous and it's not is it possible to get thermodynamic information as they change phases?

annotations.ask question: The speaker, Grace Stokes, is requesting information or clarification about the possibility of obtaining thermodynamic information in complex, heterogeneous phase-separated systems in biology.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: That's an excellent question. So can anybody provide insight here?

annotations.encourage participation: Holly Goodson invites others to provide insight, encouraging participation.
annotations.supportive response: Holly Goodson expresses a positive evaluation of the previous question.

speaker: Jan Spille
transcript: Yes. I would say it depends. It depends on your system. We we have investigated one system in the past where we were able to describe a very simple free energy function just say we have a a bulk term and a surface term and from that we can derive a condensate size distribution. And really just those two terms so just two constants, two interaction energies that describe the distribution of condensate sizes that we find. But I don't think that's going to be universally true. I think in most scenarios it's probably going to be more complex than that. That's at least my take.

annotations.signal expertise: Jan Spille explicitly states their experience and knowledge in the area of phase separation, indicating their expertise.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Actually another thermodynamic really related question that I guess I have had is many of these structures seem to be equilibrium structures but are some of them steady state structures so that there's actively energy involved in maintaining the structure? Does anybody have any information on that one? I I'm quite curious about that. Again working on the cytoskeleton right things like microtubules need energy to be polymerized and I'm wondering if there are any of these phase separated structures that are similarly energy utilizing.

annotations.ask question: The speaker is explicitly requesting information or clarification on a topic.
annotations.encourage participation: The speaker is inviting others to contribute their information or thoughts.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: I guess in bacterial examples which are probably not the norm because this has been more studied in eukaryotes but one of them is this protein that's involved in chromosome segregation. It's a CTPase so its ability to bind to DNA and then subsequently spread is dependent upon CTP hydrolysis. And then this is I don't know if you classify this as energy but it's sort of fuel-like in that the degradosome which which forms the bacterial degradosome RNC it it forms phase separated structures in bacteria that are dependent upon RNA. So when substrate's there it forms a condensate when it consumes the substrate those condensates dissolve. So if you call that energy but it's requires input.

annotations.offer feedback: The speaker provides specific examples and insights that can be seen as offering feedback on the understanding of phase-separated structures in bacteria.

speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: I guess a question that I had is to me a lot of this formation of condensates makes sense because again like if you have usually RNAs are covered with ribosomes plowing through and then you have stress and you have these free RNAs and so now you have these multivalent substrates for things to bind but then the dissolution doesn't seem like that seems much harder and I'm wondering how much more energy comes in and I know that a lot of ATPases are important for the dissolution of these granules and so I wonder if the dissolution might be you need more energy going in than the formation which is energetically favorable. Because you can't just get ribosomes in there to start translating and kicking things off.

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting information on the energy involved in the dissolution of condensates compared to their formation, and discussing the role of ATPases in this process.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Actually there is a real analogy there to the cytoskeleton right? In that in fact microtubules the energy is not used to build them the energy is used to blow it up. So I think that that's a is a very interesting point.

annotations.develop idea: She is expanding on a previous point by drawing an analogy with microtubules.
annotations.offer feedback: She is providing an example and insight that could help in understanding the topic better.

speaker: Jan Spille
transcript: So so I think there's also an analogy in the in the cell nucleus. The the condensates that we're thinking about are related to transcription and of course there's chromatin everywhere and you have active chromatin remodeling motors or enzymes ATP consuming proteins but when you delete some of them some of these condensates seem to collapse into into larger structures. So the activity might again be something that that pulls them apart or creates separation, fission, whatever it is.

speaker: Holly Goodson

speaker: Yan Yu
transcript: Yeah I have a so a question that really interests me is to relate the dynamics of the phase separation with the you know the time scale of cell signaling. So a question that I find really interesting is by what mechanism do those you know does the separation phase separation occur fast enough to accommodate the you know the rapid dynamics and interaction needed for the cell signaling because the cell signaling is very transient and involves like very rapid and dynamic I guess sometimes exchange of contents right the signaling

annotations.ask question: Yan Yu is requesting information on how phase separation occurs fast enough to accommodate the rapid dynamics and interaction needed for cell signaling, making this an explicit request for information or clarification.

speaker: Yan Yu
transcript: partners can change. So how does, you know, what by what, you know, what driving force is for such rapid, I guess, changes, interactions?

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Actually I think that's a very interesting question and that may also go back to this energy thing, right? If you think of things that just polymerize or assemble in a equilibrium way, it tends to be kind of slow to respond, but the steady state ones can be very quick. And it's an interesting question if one might be able to identify the situations where there's energy involved by seeing things that do respond very quickly. Other other comments either on that or or other questions that people had?
other: She uses expressive hand gestures to emphasize her points about energy and speed.

speaker: Gulcin Pekkurnaz
transcript: Yeah, this this is maybe a naive question because I'm not working in this field but so we had before protein-protein interactions, right? And then we said like a protein binds to each other and then I guess now if we start thinking about metabolic reactions, enzyme proteins plus metabolites, then can we think about phase separation as almost like metabolic islands, right? So and then you have like multiple islands and they're kind of doing their own thing, they're they're not a network. And then that we talked about ATP, as long as the metabolite flux is there, that island stays intact but something just stops and then it dissipates. And then what brings these phase separated, we were talking about how many phases, maybe what keeps them separate or what defines them is this the metabolite cloud in the cytoplasm. Can we think about it like that or am I being too I don't know naive or ATP-centric because of my mitochondrial vision?
other: She prefaces her question by stating she is not an expert in the field, a form of hedging.

speaker: Stephen Yi
transcript: scaffold is destroyed, you lose a part and become separated. So, part of that, back to Brian's point just now, yes, one part of the game is that you increase its specificity. You have the certain signaling molecule pathways dedicated to certain functions moving forward. The other aspect of it is that the scaffold part or condensed part itself is greatly increased the efficiency of that signal transduction at that local area as well. So I think these things can be a balance and then that's actually part of the game that I think that the signal can be regulated better.

speaker: Gulcin Pekkurnaz
transcript: I mean kind of going back to metabolism, I like that idea using maybe condensate to regulate the reaction rates. Right? So if you if you, let's say I'm thinking about neurons, metabolism has to respond really really fast. We're talking about milliseconds. And the reaction rate cannot be relying on new protein or it could be it could be maybe the enzymes are there but what's regulating the rate whether you condensate these enzymes to inactivate or kind of spread to change the equilibrium state and it's it's another way to gate signaling pathways. So it's not only about efficiency within the condensate but also kind of controlling the pathways by forming. So I like that idea a lot, I think, especially for metabolic regulation.
other: She rests her chin on her hand, a common posture indicating deep thought.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an idea previously discussed, considering how condensates could regulate reaction rates.

speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: Do we have a sense and I think some of these haven't been measured that well of is the general trend that when you throw a bunch of enzymes together they work better or they work worse? I mean so some of these things like a lot of these functions that they've ascribed to some of these granules is just like for P-body processing bodies where you have these decapping enzymes, they're like, oh, RNA degradation is happening in there because you're concentrating all these RNA decapping enzymes. But then when people have actually tried to go back and measure decapping, they don't see that. And then now there's kind of conflicting papers that if you do in vitro phase separation of the catalytic domain, you get no activity, but then maybe if you add in another protein, you get accelerated activity. So it seems very complicated and I don't know, I mean I think we need sensors of actual activity within that and not just these things whenever we measure separately they have activity and so this is what's happening inside the granule but better because I think in some cases it's going to be worse and in some cases it's going to be better, but I don't know if there's a hard and fast rule either direction.

annotations.ask question: Brian Zid is requesting information on the trend of enzyme activity when enzymes are combined, indicating he is seeking clarification or information.
annotations.identify gap: Brian Zid notes that some aspects 'haven't been measured that well,' explicitly recognizing a gap in knowledge.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: Yeah, this I really like this point Brian just brought up about essentially like so enzymes get recruited to these structures. So what, how does it affect their function? We really need biosensors to report on that because I think Brian's right, it could go either way. It could down-regulate the activity, do nothing, or up-regulate the activity. So I feel like in the field that's one thing that that that scientists struggle with is like annotating clear functions to being associated with these structures. So we really need new tools to like biosensors to address that.

annotations.develop idea: Childers is expanding on ideas previously mentioned, specifically discussing the implications of phase separation on enzyme function.
annotations.identify gap: Childers identifies a gap in knowledge about how phase separation affects enzyme function and the need for new tools like biosensors.
annotations.offer feedback: Childers provides feedback on the importance of understanding the effects of phase separation on enzyme activity and suggests using biosensors.

speaker: Stephen Yi
transcript: The other point I really want to bring up because I, that's actually a little bit focus of my lab's work. We really found that these genetic mutations, you know DNA sequences, when you have certain mutations, especially that happens a lot in these disease-causing regions, you have single nucleotide changes. That, in our current work, not totally done yet, but it looks like a big portion of those are really changing protein function through phase separation. Which is of course, very beginning of the whole field is not really much to do whatever. But actually genetic mutations, they change that, that also tells you that hey this is one of the reasons that can occur in the cell through either just accumulation of mutations. Recently, actually last week, I think we had there's a very interesting Nature paper that just came out saying that genetic mutation doesn't really happen just by cell division like what people think in the past. It can happen spontaneously, which is like totally new in the field. Which also tells you another reason for this thing to happen. If that is the case, there are also other ways for sure that can compensate, regulate, like what Seth was saying just now also is a positive regulation, negative regulation, all of those mechanisms too.

annotations.signal expertise: The speaker is explicitly stating his lab's work and recent findings, indicating his expertise in the area.
annotations.offer feedback: The speaker is offering insights and feedback on the topic of phase separation and genetic mutations.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: So maybe this would be a good time to start thinking about what might what how might we be able to harness phase separation. I guess I did want to though before we have people comment on on that, two other things to be thinking about are are first, what are the the functions of it? We've hit this somewhat but there may be some other functions that people would like to come back to. And then and then also this very important point of how we can really study what's going on inside. So maybe even take a couple of minutes here to write down some of your thoughts on one or more of those points. Just so you know also time-wise, we've got about 20-ish minutes left before we're going to need to start kind of wrapping things up. We're going to need to give Jan about 15 minutes to so we can help him extract some of the key points. Okay, so maybe one way to proceed here then would be to just to see if we can summarize what either established or or known or proposed functions are for phase separation. Anybody want to just go ahead and start?
other: Holly acts as a facilitator, structuring the conversation, managing time, and proposing a brief period for individual brainstorming.

speaker: Jan Spille
transcript: Yeah I think going back to to some of the discussions that we just had about efficiency. I think in the in the case of transcription regulation there is evidence that condensates makes the process more efficient. On the one hand in the cells we find condensates at very highly expressed gene loci. The the evidence is not so strong that that's this is really driving a specific gene. In the cell I think there's still lacking knowledge but at the same time there are also in vitro studies for say in vitro transcription reaction where if you induce the the capability to form condensates in your little in vitro transcription reaction you can make it more efficient you produce more product with the same input reagents.
other: Jan is in front of a whiteboard covered in scientific notes and diagrams.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on previous discussions about efficiency in transcription regulation, providing evidence and examples.

speaker: Holly Goodson
transcript: Other people's...

annotations.encourage participation: The speaker is inviting others to contribute their thoughts or comments.

speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: I mean they also serve as a way to segment the cytosol or segment different parts of the cell. In stress response, you might have a bunch of RNAs that are present that were non-stress RNAs and it might take more time to degrade them or you don't know how quickly the cell's going to get back out of the stress. So you can separate a certain amount of RNAs away from the translational machinery so that you can spend more resources towards translating the RNAs. So I think just it can help segment the cell in a non-membrane this way.

annotations.develop idea: Brian Zid is expanding on the concept of phase separation, providing a specific example of its potential function in cellular stress response.
annotations.propose new idea: Brian Zid introduces a specific example of how phase separation could help in segmenting the cell during stress response, which can be seen as proposing a new idea within the context of the discussion.

I think we brought up more questions than answers which is I think okay. But half of the document that I typed up is the big questions, maybe a third or so is functions and and what we need to do next to address it. I think some recurring themes were what sets what determines multi-phase assemblies, how can we create different phases, and how can molecules transition between them and how do they behave differently in different condensate, different condensate context? Do they have different functions in different condensates? And how can we on the one hand use that, maybe rational design that for synthetic biology, but how can we also understand how that is used maybe in signal transduction to to speed up certain reactions or signaling pathways? Then one of the questions was how do we structure all these condensates that we see in the cell? Are there scaffolding structures like the cytoskeleton that play a role in in organizing where phase separation happens and also controls temporal scale of condensate formation and dissolution? What we didn't talk about is that we see the same thing in the cell nucleus where we have the the chromatin scaffold. So so maybe there's a unifying theme where we have some sort of scaffolding structure that helps control phase separation in biology.

speaker: Seth Childers
transcript: Brian in your system are I guess what controls RNA assembly into these phase separated structures? Does structure play a role? speaker: Brian Zid
transcript: I don't trust most of the data out there on what's in the granules because it's all using centrifugation and then you see these longer RNAs which are also going to be sediment more readily. In general it seems like free RNAs go in there but I I'm sure there's more rules beyond that. I just don't know if we have enough data to figure out what those rules are yet. But yeah that would be cool if you had an something RNA that you could just add on to keep something out too.
